title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: existence.

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: if it consider that it has no idea of any other thing in which it
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: it can only be conceived as necessarily existing.

author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of the existence of God.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: Our mind would have no difficulty in assenting to this truth, if it
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: were, first of all, wholly free from prejudices; but as we have been
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: existence, and to imagine at will many ideas of things which neither
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: are nor have been, it easily happens, when we do not steadily fix
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: our thoughts on the contemplation of the all-perfect Being, that a
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: doubt arises as to whether the idea we have of him is not one of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: those which we frame at pleasure, or at least of that class to whose
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

text: essence existence does not pertain.

text: XVII. That the greater objective (representative) perfection there
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: is in our idea of a thing, the greater also must be the perfection
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of its cause.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: When we further reflect on the various ideas that are in us, it is
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: easy to perceive that there is not much difference among them, when
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: we consider them simply as certain modes of thinking, but that they
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: are widely different, considered in reference to the objects they
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: represent; and that their causes must be so much the more perfect
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: according to the degree of objective perfection contained in them.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: [Footnote: "as what they represent of their object has more
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: perfection."--FRENCH.] For there is no difference between this and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the case of a person who has the idea of a machine, in the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: construction of which great skill is displayed, in which
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: circumstances we have a right to inquire how he came by this idea,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: whether, for example, he somewhere saw such a machine constructed by
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: another, or whether he was so accurately taught the mechanical
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: sciences, or is endowed with such force of genius, that he was able
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of himself to invent it, without having elsewhere seen anything like
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: it; for all the ingenuity which is contained in the idea objectively
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: only, or as it were in a picture, must exist at least in its first
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: and chief cause, whatever that may be, not only objectively or
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: representatively, but in truth formally or eminently.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XVIII. That the existence of God may be again inferred from the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: above.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: Thus, because we discover in our minds the idea of God, or of an
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: all-perfect Being, we have a right to inquire into the source whence
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: we derive it; and we will discover that the perfections it
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: represents are so immense as to render it quite certain that we
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: could only derive it from an all-perfect Being; that is, from a God
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: really existing. For it is not only manifest by the natural light
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: that nothing cannot be the cause of anything whatever, and that the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: more perfect cannot arise from the less perfect, so as to be thereby
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: produced as by its efficient and total cause, but also that it is
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: impossible we can have the idea or representation of anything
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: whatever, unless there be somewhere, either in us or out of us, an
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: original which comprises, in reality, all the perfections that are
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: thus represented to us; but, as we do not in any way find in
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: ourselves those absolute perfections of which we have the idea, we
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: must conclude that they exist in some nature different from ours,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: that is, in God, or at least that they were once in him; and it most
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: manifestly follows [from their infinity] that they are still there.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XIX. That, although we may not comprehend the nature of God, there
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: is yet nothing which we know so clearly as his perfections.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: This will appear sufficiently certain and manifest to those who have
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: been accustomed to contemplate the idea of God, and to turn their
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: thoughts to his infinite perfections; for, although we may not
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: comprehend them, because it is of the nature of the infinite not to
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: be comprehended by what is finite, we nevertheless conceive them
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: more clearly and distinctly than material objects, for this reason,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: that, being simple, and unobscured by limits,[Footnote: After
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: LIMITS, "what of them we do conceive is much less confused. There
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: understanding, and which is more important than this, inasmuch as
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the consideration of an object that has no limits to its perfections
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: fills us with satisfaction and assurance."-FRENCH.] they occupy our
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: mind more fully.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: and consequently that there is a God.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: But, because every one has not observed this, and because, when we
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: have an idea of any machine in which great skill is displayed, we
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: usually know with sufficient accuracy the manner in which we
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: obtained it, and as we cannot even recollect when the idea we have
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of a God was communicated to us by him, seeing it was always in our
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: minds, it is still necessary that we should continue our review, and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: make inquiry after our author, possessing, as we do, the idea of the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: infinite perfections of a God: for it is in the highest degree
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: evident by the natural light, that that which knows something more
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: perfect than itself, is not the source of its own being, since it
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: would thus have given to itself all the perfections which it knows;
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: and that, consequently, it could draw its origin from no other being
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: than from him who possesses in himself all those perfections, that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: is, from God.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XXI. That the duration alone of our life is sufficient to
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: demonstrate the existence of God.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: The truth of this demonstration will clearly appear, provided we
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: consider the nature of time, or the duration of things; for this is
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of such a kind that its parts are not mutually dependent, and never
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: co-existent; and, accordingly, from the fact that we now are, it
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: does not necessarily follow that we shall be a moment afterwards,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: unless some cause, viz., that which first produced us, shall, as it
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: were, continually reproduce us, that is, conserve us. For we easily
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: understand that there is no power in us by which we can conserve
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: ourselves, and that the being who has so much power as to conserve
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: us out of himself, must also by so much the greater reason conserve
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: himself, or rather stand in need of being conserved by no one
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: whatever, and, in fine, be God.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XXII. That in knowing the existence of God, in the manner here
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: explained, we likewise know all his attributes, as far as they can
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: be known by the natural light alone.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: There is the great advantage in proving the existence of God in this
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: way, viz., by his idea, that we at the same time know what he is, as
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: far as the weakness of our nature allows; for, reflecting on the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: idea we have of him which is born with us, we perceive that he is
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: eternal, omniscient, omnipotent, the source of all goodness and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: truth, creator of all things, and that, in fine, he has in himself
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: all that in which we can clearly discover any infinite perfection or
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: good that is not limited by any imperfection.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XXIII. That God is not corporeal, and does not perceive by means of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: senses as we do, or will the evil of sin.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: For there are indeed many things in the world that are to a certain
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: extent imperfect or limited, though possessing also some perfection;
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: and it is accordingly impossible that any such can be in God. Thus,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: looking to corporeal nature,[Footnote: In the French, "since
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: extension constitutes the nature of body."] since divisibility is
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: included in local extension, and this indicates imperfection, it is
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: certain that God is not body. And although in men it is to some
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: degree a perfection to be capable of perceiving by means of the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: senses, nevertheless since in every sense there is passivity
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: [Footnote: In the French, "because our perceptions arise from
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: impressions made upon us from another source," i.e., than
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: ourselves.] which indicates dependency, we must conclude that God is
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: in no manner possessed of senses, and that he only understands and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: wills, not, however, like us, by acts in any way distinct, but
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: always by an act that is one, identical, and the simplest possible,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: understands, wills, and operates all, that is, all things that in
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: reality exist; for he does not will the evil of sin, seeing this is
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: but the negation of being.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XXIV. That in passing from the knowledge of God to the knowledge of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the creatures, it is necessary to remember that our understanding is
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: finite, and the power of God infinite.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: But as we know that God alone is the true cause of all that is or
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: can be, we will doubtless follow the best way of philosophizing, if,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: from the knowledge we have of God himself, we pass to the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: explication of the things which he has created, and essay to deduce
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: it from the notions that are naturally in our minds, for we will
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: thus obtain the most perfect science, that is, the knowledge of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: effects through their causes. But that we may be able to make this
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: attempt with sufficient security from error, we must use the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: precaution to bear in mind as much as possible that God, who is the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: author of things, is infinite, while we are wholly finite.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XXV. That we must believe all that God has revealed, although it
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: may surpass the reach of our faculties.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: Thus, if perhaps God reveal to us or others, matters concerning
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: himself which surpass the natural powers of our mind, such as the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: mysteries of the incarnation and of the trinity, we will not refuse
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: to believe them, although we may not clearly understand them; nor
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: will we be in any way surprised to find in the immensity of his
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: nature, or even in what he has created, many things that exceed our
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: comprehension.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XXVI. That it is not needful to enter into disputes [Footnote: "to
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: essay to comprehend the infinite."--FRENCH.] regarding the infinite,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: but merely to hold all that in which we can find no limits as
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: indefinite, such as the extension of the world, the divisibility of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the parts of matter, the number of the stars, etc.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: We will thus never embarrass ourselves by disputes about the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: infinite, seeing it would be absurd for us who are finite to
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: undertake to determine anything regarding it, and thus as it were to
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: limit it by endeavouring to comprehend it. We will accordingly give
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: ourselves no concern to reply to those who demand whether the half
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of an infinite line is also infinite, and whether an infinite number
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: is even or odd, and the like, because it is only such as imagine
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: their minds to be infinite who seem bound to entertain questions of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: this sort. And, for our part, looking to all those things in which
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: in certain senses, we discover no limits, we will not, therefore,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: affirm that they are infinite, but will regard them simply as
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: indefinite. Thus, because we cannot imagine extension so great that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: we cannot still conceive greater, we will say that the magnitude of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: possible things is indefinite, and because a body cannot be divided
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: into parts so small that each of these may not be conceived as again
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: divided into others still smaller, let us regard quantity as
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: divisible into parts whose number is indefinite; and as we cannot
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: imagine so many stars that it would seem impossible for God to
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: create more, let us suppose that their number is indefinite, and so
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: in other instances.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XXVII. What difference there is between the indefinite and the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: infinite.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: And we will call those things indefinite rather than infinite, with
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the view of reserving to God alone the appellation of infinite; in
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the first place, because not only do we discover in him alone no
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: limits on any side, but also because we positively conceive that he
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: admits of none; and in the second place, because we do not in the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: same way positively conceive that other things are in every part
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: unlimited, but merely negatively admit that their limits, if they
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: have any, cannot be discovered by us.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XXVIII. That we must examine, not the final, but the efficient,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: causes of created things.

text: XXIX. That God is not the cause of our errors.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: The first attribute of God which here falls to be considered, is
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: that he is absolutely veracious and the source of all light, so that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: it is plainly repugnant for him to deceive us, or to be properly and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: positively the cause of the errors to which we are consciously
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: subject; for although the address to deceive seems to be some mark
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of subtlety of mind among men, yet without doubt the will to deceive
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: only proceeds from malice or from fear and weakness, and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: consequently cannot be attributed to God.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

text: XXX. That consequently all which we clearly perceive is true, and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

text: that we are thus delivered from the doubts above proposed.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: Whence it follows, that the light of nature, or faculty of knowledge
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: given us by God, can never compass any object which is not true, in
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: as far as it attains to a knowledge of it, that is, in as far as the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: which arose from our ignorance on the point as to whether perhaps
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: that appear to us the most evident. The same principle ought also to
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

text: be of avail against all the other grounds of doubting that have been
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

text: suspicion, since these are of the clearest. And if we perceive
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

text: XXXI. That our errors are, in respect of God, merely negations,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: but, in respect of ourselves, privations.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: is no deceiver, if we desire to inquire into the origin and cause of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: our errors, with a view to guard against them, it is necessary to
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: and that they have no need of the actual concourse of God, in order
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: to their production; so that, when considered in reference to God,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: they are merely negations, but in reference to ourselves,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: privations.

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XXXII. That there are only two modes of thinking in us, viz., the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: perception of the understanding and the action of the will.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: For all the modes of thinking of which we are conscious may be
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: referred to two general classes, the one of which is the perception
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: or operation of the understanding, and the other the volition or
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: operation of the will. Thus, to perceive by the senses (SENTIRE), to
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: imagine, and to conceive things purely intelligible, are only
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: different modes of perceiving (PERCIP IENDI); but to desire, to be
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: averse from, to affirm, to deny, to doubt, are different modes of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: willing.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XXXIII. That we never err unless when we judge of something which
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: we do not sufficiently apprehend.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: refrain from judging of it in any way; and even when we have formed
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: a judgment regarding it, we would never fall into error, provided we
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: gave our assent only to what we clearly and distinctly perceived;
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: but the reason why we are usually deceived, is that we judge without
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: possessing an exact knowledge of that of which we judge.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: judging.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: no room to suppose that we can judge of that which we in no way
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: apprehend; but the will also is required in order to our assenting
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: to what we have in any degree perceived. It is not necessary,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: however, at least to form any judgment whatever, that we have an
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: knowledge.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: and is thus the source of our errors.

author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

text: XXXVI. That our errors cannot be imputed to God.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: praise or blame.

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: nature; and that the faults of their subjects may be frequently
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: attributed to other masters, but never to God.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

author: Descartes, René

text: leading us to believe that certain things were formerly sufficiently
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: understood by us.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: It is likewise certain that, when we approve of any reason which we
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: do not apprehend, we are either deceived, or, if we stumble on the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: truth, it is only by chance, and thus we can never possess the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: assurance that we are not in error. I confess it seldom happens that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: we judge of a thing when we have observed we do not apprehend it,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: because it is a dictate of the natural light never to judge of what
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: we do not know. But we most frequently err in this, that we presume
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: upon a past knowledge of much to which we give our assent, as to
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: something treasured up in the memory, and perfectly known to us;
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: whereas, in truth, we have no such knowledge.

author: Descartes, René

text: XLV. What constitutes clear and distinct perception.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: There are indeed a great many persons who, through their whole
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: lifetime, never perceive anything in a way necessary for judging of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: it properly; for the knowledge upon which we can establish a certain
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: and indubitable judgment must be not only clear, but also, distinct.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: I call that clear which is present and manifest to the mind giving
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: attention to it, just as we are said clearly to see objects when,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: being present to the eye looking on, they stimulate it with
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: sufficient force. and it is disposed to regard them; but the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: distinct is that which is so precise and different from all other
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: objects as to comprehend in itself only what is clear. [Footnote:
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: "what appears manifestly to him who considers it as he ought."--
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: FRENCH.]
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XLVI. It is shown, from the example of pain, that a perception may
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: be clear without being distinct, but that it cannot be distinct
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: unless it is clear.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: For example, when any one feels intense pain, the knowledge which he
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: has of this pain is very clear, but it is not always distinct; for
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: men usually confound it with the obscure judgment they form
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: regarding its nature, and think that there is in the suffering part
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: something similar to the sensation of pain of which they are alone
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: conscious. And thus perception may be clear without being distinct,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: but it can never be distinct without likewise being clear.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XLVII. That, to correct the prejudices of our early years, we must
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: consider what is clear in each of our simple [Footnote: "first."--
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: FRENCH.] notions.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: And, indeed, in our early years, the mind was so immersed in the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: body, that, although it perceived many things with sufficient
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: clearness, it yet knew nothing distinctly; and since even at that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: time we exercised our judgment in many matters, numerous prejudices
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: were thus contracted, which, by the majority, are never afterwards
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: laid aside. But that we may now be in a position to get rid of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: these, I will here briefly enumerate all the simple notions of which
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: our thoughts are composed, and distinguish in each what is clear
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: from what is obscure, or fitted to lead into error.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XLVIII. That all the objects of our knowledge are to be regarded
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: either (1) as things or the affections of things: or (2) as eternal
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: truths; with the enumeration of things.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: Whatever objects fall under our knowledge we consider either as
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: things or the affections of things,[Footnote: Things and the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: affections of things are (in the French) equivalent to "what has
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: some (i.e., a REAL) existence," as opposed to the class of "eternal
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: truths," which have merely an IDEAL existence.] or as eternal truths
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: possessing no existence beyond our thought. Of the first class the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: most general are substance, duration, order, number, and perhaps
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: also some others, which notions apply to all the kinds of things. I
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: do not, however, recognise more than two highest kinds (SUMMA
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: GENERA) of things; the first of intellectual things, or such as have
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the power of thinking, including mind or thinking substance and its
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: properties; the second, of material things, embracing extended
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: substance, or body and its properties. Perception, volition, and all
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: modes as well of knowing as of willing, are related to thinking
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: substance; on the other hand, to extended substance we refer
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: magnitude, or extension in length, breadth, and depth, figure,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: motion, situation, divisibility of parts themselves, and the like.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: There are, however, besides these, certain things of which we have
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: an internal experience that ought not to be referred either to the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: mind of itself, or to the body alone, but to the close and intimate
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: union between them, as will hereafter be shown in its place. Of this
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: class are the appetites of hunger and thirst, etc., and also the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: emotions or passions of the mind which are not exclusively mental
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: affections, as the emotions of anger, joy, sadness, love, etc.; and,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: finally, all the sensations, as of pain, titillation, light and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: colours, sounds, smells, tastes, heat, hardness, and the other
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: tactile qualities.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: XLIX. That the eternal truths cannot be thus enumerated, but that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: this is not necessary.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: What I have already enumerated we are to regard as things, or the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: qualities or modes of things. We now come to speak of eternal
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: truths. When we apprehend that it is impossible a thing can arise
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: from nothing, this proposition, EX NIHILO NIHIL FIT, is not
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: considered as somewhat existing, or as the mode of a thing, but as
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: an eternal truth having its seat in our mind, and is called a common
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: notion or axiom. Of this class are the following:--It is impossible
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the same thing can at once be and not be; what is done cannot be
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: undone; he who thinks must exist while he thinks; and innumerable
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: others, the whole of which it is indeed difficult to enumerate, but
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: this is not necessary, since, if blinded by no prejudices, we cannot
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: fail to know them when the occasion of thinking them occurs.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: L. That these truths are clearly perceived, but not equally by all
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: men, on account of prejudices.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: And, indeed, with regard to these common notions, it is not to be
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: doubted that they can be clearly and distinctly known, for otherwise
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: they would not merit this appellation: as, in truth, some of them
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: are not, with respect to all men, equally deserving of the name,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: because they are not equally admitted by all: not, however, from
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: this reason, as I think, that the faculty of knowledge of one man
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: extends farther than that of another, but rather because these
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: common notions are opposed to the prejudices of some, who, on this
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: account, are not able readily to embrace them, even although others,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: who are free from those prejudices, apprehend them with the greatest
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: clearness.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: LI. What substance is, and that the term is not applicable to God
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: and the creatures in the same sense.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: But with regard to what we consider as things or the modes of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: things, it is worth while to examine each of them by itself. By
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: substance we can conceive nothing else than a thing which exists in
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: such a way as to stand in need of nothing beyond itself in order to
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: its existence. And, in truth, there can be conceived but one
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: substance which is absolutely independent, and that is God. We
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: perceive that all other things can exist only by help of the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: concourse of God. And, accordingly, the term substance does not
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: apply to God and the creatures UNIVOCALLY, to adopt a term familiar
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: in the schools; that is, no signification of this word can be
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: distinctly understood which is common to God and them.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: LII. That the term is applicable univocally to the mind and the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: body, and how substance itself is known.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: Created substances, however, whether corporeal or thinking, may be
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: conceived under this common concept; for these are things which, in
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: order to their existence, stand in need of nothing but the concourse
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of God. But yet substance cannot be first discovered merely from its
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: being a thing which exists independently, for existence by itself is
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: not observed by us. We easily, however, discover substance itself
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: from any attribute of it, by this common notion, that of nothing
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: there are no attributes, properties, or qualities: for, from
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: perceiving that some attribute is present, we infer that some
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: existing thing or substance to which it may be attributed is also of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: necessity present.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: LIII. That of every substance there is one principal attribute, as
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: thinking of the mind, extension of the body.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: But, although any attribute is sufficient to lead us to the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: knowledge of substance, there is, however, one principal property of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: every substance, which constitutes its nature or essence, and upon
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: which all the others depend. Thus, extension in length, breadth, and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: depth, constitutes the nature of corporeal substance; and thought
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the nature of thinking substance. For every other thing that can be
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: attributed to body, presupposes extension, and is only some mode of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: an extended thing; as all the properties we discover in the mind are
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: only diverse modes of thinking. Thus, for example, we cannot
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: conceive figure unless in something extended, nor motion unless in
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: extended space, nor imagination, sensation, or will, unless in a
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: thinking thing. But, on the other hand, we can conceive extension
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: without figure or motion, and thought without imagination or
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: sensation, and so of the others; as is clear to any one who attends
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: to these matters.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: LIV. How we may have clear and distinct notions of the substance
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: which thinks, of that which is corporeal, and of God.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: And thus we may easily have two clear and distinct notions or ideas,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the one of created substance, which thinks, the other of corporeal
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: substance, provided we carefully distinguish all the attributes of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: thought from those of extension. We may also have a clear and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: distinct idea of an uncreated and independent thinking substance,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: that is, of God, provided we do not suppose that this idea
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: adequately represents to us all that is in God, and do not mix up
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: with it anything fictitious, but attend simply to the characters
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: that are comprised in the notion we have of him, and which we
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: clearly know to belong to the nature of an absolutely perfect Being.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: For no one can deny that there is in us such an idea of God, without
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: groundlessly supposing that there is no knowledge of God at all in
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the human mind.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: conceived.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: number, if, in place of mixing up with our notions of them that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: thing, in so far as it continues to exist; and, in like manner, that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: consider these things.

author: Descartes, René

text: LVI. What are modes, qualities, attributes.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: And, indeed, we here understand by modes the same with what we
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: substance as affected or varied by them, we use the term modes; when
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: from this variation it may be denominated of such a kind, we adopt
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the term qualities [to designate the different modes which cause it

author: Descartes, René

text: to be so named]; and, finally, when we simply regard these modes as
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: must be conceived as superior to change, it is not proper to say
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: attributed, and others only in our thought; and what duration and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

author: Descartes, René

author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: in the one than in the other, although there may be much more motion
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

text: in the one of the bodies than in the other. But that we may
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

text: And here we may notice the first and chief cause of our errors. In
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: these thoughts to anything existing beyond itself, but simply felt
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: pain when the body was hurt, or pleasure when anything beneficial to
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the body occurred, or if the body was so highly affected that it was
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: colours, and the like, which in truth are representative of nothing
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: existing out of our mind, and which vary according to the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: diversities of the parts and modes in which the body is affected.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: [Footnote: "which vary according to the diversities of the movements
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: that pass from all parts of our body to the part of the brain to
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: which it (the mind) is closely joined and united."--FRENCH.] The
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: and the like, which were not presented to it as sensations but as
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: existing out of thought, although it did not yet observe this
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: difference between these two kinds of perceptions. And afterwards
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

text: that it can of its own inherent power move itself in various ways,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: useful and avoided what was detrimental; the mind, which was closely
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: connected with it, reflecting on the objects it pursued or avoided,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: remarked, for the first time, that they existed out of itself, and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

text: of external objects).--FRENCH.] and as it only considered other
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

text: Wherefore if we would philosophize in earnest, and give ourselves to
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the search after all the truths we are capable of knowing, we must,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: in the first place, lay aside our prejudices; in other words, we
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: must take care scrupulously to withhold our assent from the opinions
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: we have formerly admitted, until upon new examination we discover
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: that they are true. We must, in the next place, make an orderly
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: review of the notions we have in our minds, and hold as true all and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: only those which we will clearly and distinctly apprehend. In this
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

author: Descartes, René

text: of them. Besides the notions we have of God and of our mind, we will
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: divided, etc., and also of certain sensations that affect us, as of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: pain, colours, tastes, etc., although we do not yet know the cause
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of our being so affected; and, comparing what we have now learne'd,

author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: knowledge of them, we will acquire the habit of forming clear and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: Having now ascertained certain principles of material things, which
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of God.

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
