text: CXCVI. That the soul perceives only in so far as it is in the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: brain.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: It is clearly established, however, that the soul does not perceive
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: in so far as it is in each member of the body, but only in so far as
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: it is in the brain, where the nerves by their movements convey to it
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the diverse actions of the external objects that touch the parts of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the body in which they are inserted. For, in the first place, there
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: are various maladies, which, though they affect the brain alone, yet
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: bring disorder upon, or deprive us altogether of the use of, our
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: senses, just as sleep, which affects the brain only, and yet takes
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: from us daily during a great part of our time the faculty of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: perception, which afterwards in our waking state is restored to us.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: The second proof is, that though there be no disease in the brain,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: [or in the members in which the organs of the external senses are],
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: it is nevertheless sufficient to take away sensation from the part
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of the body where the nerves terminate, if only the movement of one
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of the nerves that extend from the brain to these members be
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: obstructed in any part of the distance that is between the two. And
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the last proof is, that we sometimes feel pain as if in certain of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: our members, the cause of which, however, is not in these members
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: where it is felt, but somewhere nearer the brain, through which the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: nerves pass that give to the mind the sensation of it. I could
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: establish this fact by innumerable experiments; I will here,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: however, merely refer to one of them. A girl suffering from a bad
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: ulcer in the hand, had her eyes bandaged whenever the surgeon came
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: to visit her, not being able to bear the sight of the dressing of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the sore; and, the gangrene having spread, after the expiry of a few
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: days the arm was amputated from the elbow [without the girl's
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: knowledge]; linen cloths tied one above the other were substituted
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: in place of the part amputated, so that she remained for some time
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: without knowing that the operation had been performed, and meanwhile
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: she complained of feeling various pains, sometimes in one finger of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the hand that was cut off, and sometimes in another. The only
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: explanation of this is, that the nerves which before stretched
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: downwards from the brain to the hand, and then terminated in the arm
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: close to the elbow, were there moved in the same way as they
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: required to be moved before in the hand for the purpose of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: impressing on the mind residing in the brain the sensation of pain
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: in this or that finger. [And this clearly shows that the pain of the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: hand is not felt by the mind in so far as it is in the hand, but in
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: so far as it is in the brain.]

author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

text: CXCVII. That the nature of the mind is such that from the motion
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: alone of body the various sensations can be excited in it.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: In the next place, it can be proved that our mind is of such a
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: nature that the motions of the body alone are sufficient to excite
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: in it all sorts of thoughts, without it being necessary that these
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: should in any way resemble the motions which give rise to them, and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: especially that these motions can excite in it those confused
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: thoughts called sensations (SENSUS, SENSATIONES). For we see that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: words, whether uttered by the voice or merely written, excite in our
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: minds all kinds of thoughts and emotions. On the same paper, with
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the same pen and ink, by merely moving the point of the pen over the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: paper in a particular way, we can trace letters that will raise in
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the minds of our readers the thoughts of combats, tempests, or the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: furies, and the passions of indignation and sorrow; in place of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: which, if the pen be moved in another way hardly different from the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: former, this slight change will cause thoughts widely different from
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the above, such as those of repose, peace, pleasantness, and the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: quite opposite passions of love and joy. Some one will perhaps
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: object that writing and speech do not immediately excite in the mind
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: any passions, or imaginations of things different from the letters
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: and sounds, but afford simply the knowledge of these, on occasion of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: which the mind, understanding the signification of the words,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: afterwards excites in itself the imaginations and passions that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: correspond to the words. But what will be said of the sensations of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: pain and titillation? The motion merely of a sword cutting a part of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: our skin causes pain, [but does not on that account make us aware of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the motion or figure of the sword]. And it is certain that this
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: sensation of pain is not less different from the motion that causes
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: it, or from that of the part of our body which the sword cuts, than
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: are the sensations we have of colour, sound, odour, or taste. On
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: this ground we may conclude that our mind is of such a nature that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the motions alone of certain bodies can also easily excite in it all
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the other sensations, as the motion of a sword excites in it the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: sensation of pain.

author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy

text: CXCVIII. That by our senses we know nothing of external objects
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: beyond their figure [or situation], magnitude, and motion.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: Besides, we observe no such difference between the nerves as to lead
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: us to judge that one set of them convey to the brain from the organs
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of the external senses anything different from another, or that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: anything at all reaches the brain besides the local motion of the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: nerves themselves. And we see that local motion alone causes in us
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: not only the sensation of titillation and of pain, but also of light
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: and sounds. For if we receive a blow on the eye of sufficient force
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: to cause the vibration of the stroke to reach the retina, we see
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: numerous sparks of fire, which, nevertheless, are not out of our
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: eye; and when we stop our ear with our finger, we hear a humming
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: sound, the cause of which can only proceed from the agitation of the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: air that is shut up within it. Finally, we frequently observe that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: heat [hardness, weight], and the other sensible qualities, as far as
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: they are in objects, and also the forms of those bodies that are
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: purely material, as, for example, the forms of fire, are produced in
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: them by the motion of certain other bodies, and that these in their
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: turn likewise produce other motions in other bodies. And we can
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: easily conceive how the motion of one body may be caused by that of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: another, and diversified by the size, figure, and situation of its
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: parts, but we are wholly unable to conceive how these same things
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: (viz., size, figure, and motion), can produce something else of a
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: nature entirely different from themselves, as, for example, those
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: substantial forms and real qualities which many philosophers suppose
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: to be in bodies; nor likewise can we conceive how these qualities or
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: forms possess force to cause motions in other bodies. But since we
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: know, from the nature of our soul, that the diverse motions of body
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: are sufficient to produce in it all the sensations which it has, and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: since we learn from experience that several of its sensations are in
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: reality caused by such motions, while we do not discover that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: anything besides these motions ever passes from the organs of the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: external senses to the brain, we have reason to conclude that we in
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: no way likewise apprehend that in external objects, which we call
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: light, colour, smell, taste, sound, heat or cold, and the other
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: tactile qualities, or that which we call their substantial forms,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: unless as the various dispositions of these objects which have the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: power of moving our nerves in various ways. [Footnote: "the diverse
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: figures, situations, magnitudes, and motions of their parts."--

author: Descartes, René

text: French.]

text: CXCIX. That there is no phenomenon of nature whose explanation has
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: been omitted in this treatise.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: And thus it may be gathered, from an enumeration that is easily
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: made, that there is no phenomenon of nature whose explanation has
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: been omitted in this treatise; for beyond what is perceived by the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: senses, there is nothing that can be considered a phenomenon of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: nature. But leaving out of account motion, magnitude, figure, [and
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the situation of the parts of each body], which I have explained as
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: they exist in body, we perceive nothing out of us by our senses
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: except light, colours, smells, tastes, sounds, and the tactile
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: qualities; and these I have recently shown to be nothing more, at
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: least so far as they are known to us, than certain dispositions of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: the objects, consisting in magnitude, figure, and motion.

text: CC. That this treatise contains no principles which are not
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: universally received; and that this philosophy is not new, but of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: all others the most ancient and common.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: But I am desirous also that it should be observed that, though I
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: have here endeavoured to give an explanation of the whole nature of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: material things, I have nevertheless made use of no principle which
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: was not received and approved by Aristotle, and by the other
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: philosophers of all ages; so that this philosophy, so far from being
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: new, is of all others the most ancient and common: for I have in
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: truth merely considered the figure, motion, and magnitude of bodies,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: and examined what must follow from their mutual concourse on the
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: principles of mechanics, which are confirmed by certain and daily
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: experience. But no one ever doubted that bodies are moved, and that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: they are of various sizes and figures, according to the diversity of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: which their motions also vary, and that from mutual collision those
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: somewhat greater than others are divided into many smaller, and thus
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: change figure. We have experience of the truth of this, not merely
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: by a single sense, but by several, as touch, sight, and hearing: we
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: also distinctly imagine and understand it. This cannot be said of
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: any of the other things that fall under our senses, as colours,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: sounds, and the like; for each of these affects but one of our
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: senses, and merely impresses upon our imagination a confused image
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of itself, affording our understanding no distinct knowledge of what
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: it is.

text: CCI. That sensible bodies are composed of insensible particles.
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: But I allow many particles in each body that are perceived by none
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of our senses, and this will not perhaps be approved of by those who
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: take the senses for the measure of the knowable. [We greatly wrong
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: human reason, however, as appears to me, if we suppose that it does
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: not go beyond the eye-sight]; for no one can doubt that there are
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: bodies so small as not to be perceptible by any of our senses,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: provided he only consider what is each moment added to those bodies
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: that are being increased little by little, and what is taken from
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: those that are diminished in the same way. A tree increases daily,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: and it is impossible to conceive how it becomes greater than it was

author: Descartes, René

text: before, unless we at the same time conceive that some body is added

author: Descartes, René

text: to it. But who ever observed by the senses those small bodies that
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: are in one day added to a tree while growing? Among the philosophers
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: at least, those who hold that quantity is indefinitely divisible,
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: ought to admit that in the division the parts may become so small as
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: to be wholly imperceptible. And indeed it ought not to be a matter
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
author: Descartes, René

text: of surprise, that we are unable to perceive very minute bodies; for
title: Selections from the Principles of Philosophy
